text: nice little minimal tooltip plugin <http://codyhouse.co/gem/points-of-interest/>

attachments.text: Use this resource to highlight the points of interest of your products. Just a click to open a brief description of each point, allowing your user to get a deep
attachments.fallback: Use this resource to highlight the points of interest of your products. Just a click to open a brief description of each point, allowing your user to get a deep

text: Hey Design team, just talked to Dustin about a design question him and Philip were asking that I would like to start a discussion about (it's an ambiguous topic that's been on my mind for a while). When assembling pitch decks and using imagery found online by other artists/photographers for internal proposals and progress decks...  where do we officially land on crediting original owners and using imagery that's not clearly labeled for reuse?
I bring this up 1) as a professional/ethical consideration and 2) to propose the possibility of using a stock photography account for these types of design needs.
<@U02AVBGQC|dustin> has joined the channel
for my part, if it's not going out into the public - I don't have any issue with it.
though this is a timely question: on friday we sent out a deck that was intentionally ALL other peoples/companies images
and included a page in the deck that just said basically: this is all other people's stuff
obviously though there are limits. I would never want to present something that could be misconstrued as our work

i agree with justin - if its not public (just for presentations/pitch decks), I'm fine with it. that being said, I imagine that we do have some royalty free imagery lying around that we have purchsed ( i know that i have a handful for samsung), and we should post those on NAS somewhere for people to draw from where appropriate.
NAS/uncorked/_Resources/Royalty-Free Images - Purchased

I get that. But I think another reason I bring this up is that there's an unavoidably weird feeling I get finding a good image to use and having to crop out the copyright watermark on it, even though it's not for direct profit.
late to this conversation - but agree that non-public use is pretty fair game
hm yeah i don't usually use images that have watermarks on them
But do watermarked images set themselves apart from non-watermarked images as far as copyrighting is concerned?
i don't think they do - beyond that they're watermarked
nope, but i don't have any ethical dilemma when cropping them out :grinning:
right
Trent - do you think we need to be more ethical in this particular point?
I do
Or at least I personally do
that's what i'm asking
i'd be happy to, though I don't know of any place of quality and price that balances these things out
if you know of any, i'm all ears
shutterstock is not too bad, actually
or at least i found some pretty good, affordable images there for samsung
better than istock
i'm happy to put this in hopper for consideration of things.
but know that there's a balance that we'll need to strike in general. For me, the ethical line falls in that we never use said work in paid work
I understand that too, but brought it up because it still ends up feeling like a grey area to me.

Not a designer, just providing my 2 cents, but for presentations I build, I like to include some form of image credit for any images not my own (and I usually place a 'Personal Photo' tag on those). I've never really paid for an image, but I think it is worth giving the audience a chance to see the original creator in some way. Also helpful for researching the deck/image later if the deck is given out.
there are also services like this <http://deathtothestockphoto.com/> which have nice photos but its dfinitely not searchable or anything. you get what you get

attachments.title: Death to the Stock Photo -
attachments.text: Join us to rid the world of bad stock photography.
attachments.fallback: Death to the Stock Photo: Death to the Stock Photo -

text: adding tiny mouse-type image credits is certainly an option
I like it since it's quick, and provides direct access to the source in the form of a link

To clarify my grey area comment, it's grey to me in where I'm supposed to land on this, not trying to imply this is an area that needs to be completely changed/reformed. And I think the dialogue is necessary to be sure everyone is on the same page.
I also have appreciated when other designers use tiny corner captions to credit image sources.
i think thats typically the price of a creative commons photo for commercial use... a written image credit somewhere
but for documents that only a handful of people are seeing... eh
iamewald how would you feel if some rando design studio was using your imagery for pitch decks?
That's fair
i can say with certainty that we fall pretty far on the respectful side of things, industry wide
as long as they're not actively selling my images, i honestly don't care
and know that that's happened before
same goes for student work
in fact
how i got the last two photography things were exactly that
in both cases, they literally pitched the client using my imagery
like the images WERE the pitch vs. window dressing
uncredited
and unknown until after the fact
the fact that any of the actual creative work in our decks is, kanye apart, ours
that is - the stuff we sell is actively ours
yes, we borrow images for things like pitch decks — A dinosaur illustration or something
and yes we do the same for client presentations
like i said, i don't know of a cost effective way to do things like sell OMSI trapit for instance
because you need the images to help sell the dream
and there's no way we can afford all the imagery in that case
and a small tip in credit on every page takes away from that dream
i'm open to considering options — including a whrilwind creation of our own stuff for sure
but i don't think this should keep us up at night
Thanks David, this is all good. And doesn't keep me up, just been a question on the mind for the last several months (large amounts of pitch decks will do things like that ;)
i hear you
i've worked places — big places
where they just put uncredited, unpaid stuff in actual final work
hah
which is obviously out of line
and why i don't sweat this
Haven't had a chance to experience that opposite end of the spectrum, and why I'm able to sweat it.

Late to the party, but agree with most. I see pitch decks as kind of an understood, fair-use world. They're private, they're _usually_ on spec, and shouldn't be represented as "formal work." As someone who has spent a great deal of time searching google images for pitch decks, I do agree that a subscription service would help to secure better quality images more quickly. But ethically? There's probably bigger fish to fry...

Personally, I think the problems with font licensing and "sharing" is a FAR worse crime of ethics. Especially when shared with clients start to pass back and forth.
ha. very good point on fonts
And that's not just becasue I went to type-con last year...
but they — type designers as a whole — were freaking out
i can't remember the last time i (or any employer of mine) purchased a font for a project
i suddenly feel very vindicated for always being super-diligent about fonts in the past
that's great. Just know there are a lot of type-nerds who really appreciate it. (i felt so bad after the conference looking through my type directory)
Good point Matt. I think things are better for Type folks now than a couple of years back b/c Typekit but it's still pretty bad.
seems like Adobe has it pretty well figured out. the little guys are hurting for sure.
<http://www.typesample.com|www.typesample.com>
TypeSample is like InstaPaper for fonts. They have a chrome extension and bookmarklet that allow you to save type samples you see on the web. Pretty rad.
very neat!
that's dope!
